conclusion: Need to analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval.
The graph shows the velocity as a function of time.
The velocity increases from 0 m/s to 20 m/s over the first 10 seconds.
After 10 seconds, the velocity decreases to 10 m/s over the next 5 seconds.
The distance fallen can be found by calculating the area under the velocity-time graph.
For the first 10 seconds, the velocity increases linearly from 0 m/s to 20 m/s.
The area under the first 10 seconds can be calculated using the formula for the area of a triangle.
Average velocity during the first 10 seconds is 10 m/s.
Area under the first 10 seconds is 50 meters.
The total distance fallen is the sum of the distances fallen in the first 10 seconds and the next 5 seconds.
For the next 5 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 20 m/s to 10 m/s.
Average velocity during the next 5 seconds is 15 m/s.
Area under the next 5 seconds is 37.5 meters.
The total distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is 50 meters, which is less than 100 meters.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is less than 100 meters.
